description.narrative: Core support to Palestinian Medical Relief Society (PMRS) which works with the right to health and with health service provision in all of Palestine including Area C and Gaza.

Den föreslagna insatsen är en fortsättning på ett långsiktigt stöd till PMRS som genom tidigare samarbetsfaser har spelat en avgörande roll i sin förmåga att leverera viktig och kvalitativ hälsovård i hela det palestinska området, med särskild tonvikt på område C, östra Jerusalem och Gaza. Anledningen till Sidas ettåriga stöd (2014) till PMRS på 7 900 000 kronor är det förväntade införandet av stöd till hälsa i den nya resultatstrategin samt att PMRS sannolikt kommer att vara en del av en bredare portfölj som genomförs under 2015 och framåt. Insatsen syftar till att bidra till att förbättra det palestinska sjukvårdssystemet genom att erbjuda tjänster som är upp till standard, inte bara i mängd utan också i kvalité. PMRS syftar till att samarbeta med Hälsoministeriet och andra relevanta aktörer inom hälsosektorn för att bidra till att stärka kapaciteten hos palestinska myndigheten (PA) genom överförande av praxis och modeller samt att fortsätta att förespråka rättigheter för de mest utsatta och marginaliserade i områden som inte nås av PA. Insatsens totala budget för 2014 är $ 7,365.000 varav PMRS egna medel utgör ca $ 1.900.000 och resterande är bidrag från Sida , Medico International, Oxfam Novib , Luxemburg, Care International, Diakonia och andra.
The proposed intervention is continuation of a long-term support to PMRS since it has been playing a crucial role due to its capacity to deliver important and good quality health services in all of oPt with specially emphasis on Area C, East Jerusalem and Gaza. Sida's one year support ( 2014) to PMRS with 7,900,000 SEK is due to an anticipated inclusion of support to health services in the new strategy and PMRS is then likely to be part of a broader portfolio being implemented in 2015 and onward. The intervention aims at contributing to the improvement of the Palestinian health system through offering services that are up to standard not only in quantity but also in quality. It aims to collaborate with the Moth and other relevant partners in the health sector and contributing to strengthening the capacity of the PA through transferring its best practices and models and continue to advocate for the rights of the most vulnerable and marginalised in ares unreachable by the PA. The intervention total budget for 2014 is $7,365.000 out of which the own organisations' own funding is approximately $1,900,000 and the remaining is contributed by Sida, Medico International, Oxfam Novib, Luxemburg, Care international, Diakonia, and others. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- supplementary Contribution Decision 2015
The same reasons mentioned above are the basis for this supplementary contribution decision . 2015 interventions budget is $8,044.580 (69,912.79 SEK) ( out of which own organisation's funding is approximately $1,900.000 ( 16,513,000 SEK)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: PMRS has clearly reported on their outcomes and outputs for 2015. A decrease in beneficiaries for some outputs is justified because in 2014 the high number of beneficiaries was related to the 2014 war on Gaza, whereby PMRS had to deploy more mobile clinics and emergency health workers were needed to aid the injured.
The transfer of health models (non-communicable diseases, women's health, youth health, community-based rehabilitation, mobile clinics, and primary health care) had already been done in 2013, but in 2014 and 2015, PMRS held conferences to give stakeholders the opportunity to discuss the health models. The models were also introduced to other countries (for instance the MoH in Kuwait), but they have not been transferred yet. In terms of health education and awareness, a sharp increase in beneficiaries was reported as PMRS focused in 2015 on working with young people and involved them in preventive care activities, and emergency preparedness and first aid services.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
